text:
March Madness preview: Wednesday's NCAA tournament First Four games Breaking down the final First Four NCAA tournament games in Dayton, Ohio. Post to Facebook March Madness preview: Wednesday's NCAA tournament First Four games Breaking down the final First Four NCAA tournament games in Dayton, Ohio.  //usat.ly/2nmeMFj   March Madness preview: Wednesday's NCAA tournament First Four games Eddie Timanus , USA TODAY Sports 2:22   CLOSE x Share Legendary broadcaster Dick Vitale was in our studios breaking down all the NCAA tournament story lines. USC Trojans guard Elijah Stewart dunks over Arizona Wildcats center Dusan Ristic. (Photo: Casey Sapio, USA TODAY Sports)   
Breaking down the two First Four NCAA tournament games in Dayton, Ohio. No. 16 North Carolina Central (25-8) vs. No. 16 UC Davis (22-12) 
Midwest Region 
Time, TV : 6:40 p.m. ET, truTV 
► Why North Carolina Central will win : The Eagles are an athletic group that likes to push the pace. They aren’t afraid to make the risky pass, which can be a minus but could serve them well in this setting. Coach LeVelle Moton also has several bench contributors whom he can count on for double-digit minutes if needed. 
► Why UC Davis will win : This is the Aggies’ first rodeo, but not so for coach Jim Les, who led his alma mater Bradley to the Sweet 16 in 2006. He was known for his long-range shooting and precision passing as a player, and he has taught his own guards how to find openings. No. 11 Providence (20-12) vs. No. 11 Southern California (24-9) 
East Region 
Time, TV : 9:10 p.m. ET, truTV 
► Why Providence will win : By season’s end, the Friars were as hot as any team not named Villanova in the Big East. They have good size throughout their lineup and are equipped to take advantage if the Trojans have an off shooting night. 
► Why USC will win : Don’t think for a minute that the USC veterans aren’t aware of who sent them packing from the tournament a year ago. The Trojans will be ready for this rematch with the Friars. Bennie Boatwright has excellent touch and range for a big man and can be counted on at the free-throw line as well.
